awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Mechanism as a Driving Force in Gold(I) Catalyzed Alkyne Functionalizations
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Amanda C. Jones of Wake Forest University is investigating improving the efficiency of gold-based catalysts by examining the chemical mechanisms by which they act. Gold catalysts are powerful and environmentally friendly reagents that can be used for the production of pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals. The economic feasibility of their use, however, is dependent on the ability to use them in minimal quantities with maximum recycling. The mechanistic understanding being pursued by this project is crucial to achieving a high level of efficiency. 

Professor Jones is examining the distinct reactivity of organogold compounds and the ability of cationic gold complexes to mediate addition reactions, transmetalations, and rearrangements via gold carbenes. The unifying theme is the current gap in information about the formation and reactivity of alkyl gold (C(sp3)-Au) intermediates. The approach is two-pronged and incorporates first the synthesis of organogold compounds and gold coordination complexes, and second, kinetic studies on those structures to elucidate mechanisms and improve future design of catalytic reactions. Development of a rapid-injection NMR apparatus will contribute to these studies by opening up the window of obtainable kinetic data. The project provides training for undergraduate and graduate students who will learn to execute chemical and scientific methods, conduct responsible research, and think critically about reaction mechanisms. Professor Jones is also developing reading clubs as a way to encourage early and life-long engagement with science. By exposing community members and elementary school students to novels with scientific themes, as well as the prose or biographical writings of "dual personalities," individuals who have achieved success in supposedly disparate areas (scientist vs. writer, artist, musician, activist), Professor Jones is working to cultivate positive attitudes toward science.  These efforts contribute a non-traditional element to the recruitment of students to scientific fields.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In-depth understanding of reaction mechanisms is critical to optimization of metal catalysts and assisting chemists in reaching the full potential of synthetic utility and catalyst control. Nobel Prize work involving Palladium and Ruthenium reveal the power that can come from sustained efforts to improve and understand catalytic systems. This project addressed fundamental questions regarding the method of action of gold(I) catalysts supported by phosphorous ligands in the activation of alkynes and alkenes. The future successes of organic synthetic chemists to continue to design efficient and diverse methods to prepare medicines and materials relies on the ability to use a broad array of catalysts with high efficiency and control. Gold catalysts show high potential to this end, but gaps in mechanistic understanding prevent reliable predictions about ligand impact on catalyst efficacy.

A kinetic study of alkyl gold formation during hydroamination revealed that a key organogold intermediate does not react on the same timescale as catalytic cyclization to the final organic product, meaning the organogold intermediate cannot be kinetically relevant. This suggests a new mechanistic model needs to be considered for this reaction that has high utility in preparing enantioenriched nitrogen heterocycles. A series of new phosphine ligands were designed and shown to allow generation of more electrophilic gold catalysts with enhanced stability. Work to be published studies show how careful choice of ligand structure can be used to minimize the formation of catalytically unproductive gold byproducts. Other work to be published studies also show how an evolving understanding of solvent effects can lead to significant enhancements of reactivity with inexpensive additives. This work put together will improve chemists' ability to rationally design optimal reaction conditions for important gold catalyzed processes.

The mechanistic work supported by this grant provided an arena for education and professional development. Undergraduate and graduate students learned chemical and scientific methods, problem solving skills, integrity in research, obtained presentation opportunities, and participated in projects that required deep thinking about chemical processes. In parallel to research and mentoring efforts, this grant supported community outreach in literacy. In partnership with the Wake Forest University Freedom School, a program for elementary and middle-school students aimed at strengthening children's reading skills and closing achievement gaps that are often correlated with the absence of formal schooling in the summer, the grant provided support for chemistry outreach activities with Freedom School Scholars. These activities included introductions to concepts of chemical bonding by engaging students in the use of chemical model kits and the hosting of a "Summer STEM reading Challenge" wherein copies of science and science-fiction titles were provided. Each summer the activities culminated in a "Tie-Dye Day" to connect science learning to real-life concepts.

Overall, this project has contributed to a firmer understanding of foundational mechanistic processes in gold chemistry. The project increased chemical and scientific literacy by engaging students in projects focused on understanding chemical processes and contributing positively to young students experiences of science and learning. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2022
Modified by: Amanda C Jones
